body.section:
The plugin execution requires :
Java 1.5 (as Tapestry 5 do)
Maven 2+ (tested on 2.0.10 and 2.2.1)

ul.li: Carefully javadoc your component classes and their attributes annotated with @Parameter (already done i hope, isn't it ? :))
Open the pom.xml in your library project

Paste the following configuration is your plugins descriptor :
<plugin> <groupId>fr.exanpe</groupId> <artifactId>tapestry-tldgen</artifactId> <version>${set the version here}</version> <executions> <execution> <goals> <goal>tld-generate</goal> </goals> <phase>process-classes</phase> <configuration> <uri>${set your tld uri here}</uri> <namespace>${set your tld defaut namespace here}</namespace> <rootPackage>${set your root package here}</rootPackage> <encoding>${set your source file encoding here}</encoding> </configuration> </execution> </executions> </plugin>
Run a build and get your tld from target/ folder
Nevermind about the tldgen-components-info.xml file generated. We only generate it to provide Javadoc information back to the plugin.

tr.td: The root package to scan the components. Do not append "components" in the end, root only is required.
The namespace of the taglib. Default is "t" .
The source file encoding. Default is your plateform encoding
The tld file location. Default is ${project.build.directory}/${project.build.finalName}.tld

body.section:
To get advantage of the tld information in your tml coding, execute the instructions on the following page with some modificaitons :
Tapestry 5 and JSP Editor for Eclipse
Set your key field as "tapestry-library:${libkey}", ${libkey} the key defined in the library Module class (Tapestry 5 doc on library).
In your tml, just define your tld in your root tag. (xmlns:${namespace}="tapestry-library:${libkey}")
This is the standard Tapestry configuration, nothing has to be changed here to use the tld . A simple binding is performed in the XML Catalog.
Add as many declaration as you want in your tml. The link is performed with each tld declared.
